conclusion: A charged particle (charge q > 0, mass m) is launched horizontally with velocity v₀
Above the baffles is a uniform downward electric field E
Between the baffles is a uniform magnetic field (perpendicular outward)
The particle enters the magnetic field at point P
The particle's velocity direction makes a 60° angle with PQ when entering the magnetic field
We need to find the distance from the launch position to point P
The particle experiences a downward force F = qE in the electric field, causing a downward acceleration a = qE/m
The horizontal velocity remains constant at v₀ because there's no horizontal force

The vertical motion follows the equations of uniformly accelerated motion with vertical acceleration a = qE/m, initial vertical velocity v_y = 0, and final vertical velocity at point P: v_y(P) = (qE/m)t
The time to reach point P is t = s/v₀ since horizontal velocity is constant
When the particle reaches point P, horizontal velocity v_x(P) = v₀ and vertical velocity v_y(P) = (qE·s)/(m·v₀)
The angle between the particle's velocity direction and PQ is 60° at point P, giving tan(θ) = v_y(P)/v_x(P) = (qE·s)/(m·v₀²)
Since PQ is vertical, the angle between velocity and PQ is 90° - θ = 60°, therefore θ = 30°
Rearranging to find s gives s = (m·v₀²)/(qE·√3)
The distance from the particle's launch position to point P is s = m·v₀²/(qE·√3)
